metadata.titel_preek: An der Furt – Da rang einer mit ihm bis zur Morgenröte

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human subject (Jakob/Hearer) must navigate painful life transitions and 'wrestle' with a dark, attacking God to extract a blessing and achieve a new identity/reconciliation.

tekstueel_bewijs: Jakob ringt mit Gott... Er kämpft die ganze Nacht.
Wir sollen nicht verzweifeln, sondern dieses ringend bestehen.
Ich ringe, ich kämpfe wie Jakob, so möchte ich werden.

object.identificatie: Blessing (Segen) and the ability to say 'Yes' to suffering.
tekstueel_bewijs: Ich lasse dich nicht, du segnest mich denn.
Einverstanden werden mit dem, was geschieht.
Gott überfällt uns... Gott hat auch die Kraft, furchtbare Dinge auf uns zu häufen.

ontvanger.positie_hoorder: Does hearer identify with Subject or Receiver?

helper.identificatie: Human willpower, memories of songs/childhood, and 'boldness' (Dreistigkeit).
tekstueel_bewijs: Das Ringen, das müssen wir schon selber tun.
Mach uns hungrig nach dir lehr uns beten.
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Opponent/Object, not the Helper.

tegenstander.identificatie: The 'Dämon' (God in disguise), Fear, and Resignation.
tekstueel_bewijs: Ein übermächtiges Wesen greift ihn an.
Die Gespenster, die uns bedrohen: Bitterkeit, Resignation.
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is God Himself acting as a dark force that must be overcome by human persistence.

secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Activist/Hearer
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Peace and Bread for the hungry.
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: Wrestling with God is equated with political 'Nötigung' (coercion) for justice.

voorbeelden_mens_subject: Wir müssen über den dunklen Fluss.
Ich halte an dir fest, Gott.
Wir werfen uns Gott in den Weg.

voorbeelden: Das Ringen, das müssen wir schon selber tun.
Wir müssen über den dunklen Fluss.
Wir mögen in diesem Kampf Abschied nehmen lernen.
Beten kann man nur, wenn man durstig ist.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon is a 'Recruitment' sermon. It focuses on awakening the human will (Vouloir) to struggle against a silent or hostile God.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From S2 (Darkness) through ~S2 (Rejecting liberal God) to S1 (Blessing) via human effort (~S1).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved by the human subject refusing to let go until God yields a blessing.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Very high. S2 is seen as the primary face of God.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While using biblical imagery, the 'engine' is entirely anthropocentric. God is the obstacle/opponent, and the human will is the hero that achieves the blessing through 'wrestling'.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Das Ringen, das müssen wir schon selber tun, niemand kommt daran vorbei.
Wir 'nötigen' Gott... Ich lasse dich nicht, du segnest mich denn.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Jakob is the model for the modern 'struggler'.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: God pursues and breaks the self-reliant Jakob to grant him a grace he cannot win by strength.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Exhaustion or Promethean pride; the burden of 'winning' the blessing lies on the hearer.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Synergism where the human 'struggle' is the condition for grace.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: Strongly coherent as a narrative of 'existential struggle', but theologically incoherent regarding the nature of a Savior.
spanning_punten: God is both the attacker and the one who must be coerced into blessing.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Ich ringe, ich kämpfe wie Jakob, so möchte ich werden.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The hearer must find their own 'Dreistigkeit' (boldness).

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is seen as 'resignation' or 'giving up', rather than ontological separation.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon functions as a call to existential heroism. Jakob is the Subject, God is the Opponent/Helper-Object.

subject_herpositionering.huidige_probleem: The hearer is told they MUST wrestle to get the blessing.
subject_herpositionering.voorgestelde_herpositionering: God is the Subject who 'wrestles' Jakob to the ground to kill his ego and give him a new life.
subject_herpositionering.voorbeeld_revisie: Instead of 'We must wrestle with God,' use 'God refuses to let us go until He has broken our self-reliance and blessed us.'

identificatie_herstel.strategie: Focus on Jakob's limp (weakness) as the gift of God, not his strength in wrestling.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Pouvoir (God's power given to the weak)
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Emphasize that we CANNOT cross the river, but God carries us.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: The opponent (Dark God/Fate) is already very intense.
tegenstander_intensivering.theologische_rationale: The sermon already has a 'heavy' opponent, but lacks a 'heavy' Savior.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.probleem: Ethics (political action) is fused with Soteriology (wrestling for blessing).
narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: 1. God saves the drowning Jakob. 2. The saved Jakob walks differently in the world.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: The sermon is rhetorically powerful and existentially honest, but structurally Pelagian. It places the burden of 'blessing' on the human will.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorically, the sermon is moving and personal. Semiotically, it is a 'Law' sermon because the Subject is 'I/We'.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis often misses that 'wrestling' in the text is a defeat for Jakob (he limps), whereas the sermon treats it as a victory of his will.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that God has been demoted from 'Subject' to 'Object of human desire/coercion'.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses 'God' frequently, but almost always as the target of human action or as a synonym for 'Fate'.
